ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Mechanisms and uses of organometallic catalysis. How to approach & solve a scientific problem; how to design and carry out useful experiments; how to think mechanistically about a reaction. Almost all catalysis, but also a good mix of fundamental transition metal chemistry and some organic chemistry.
Organometallic chemistry. Elementary reaction for this project, some useful applications.

You learn many different and cool applications in organometallics and understand the chemistry behind them, how chemists think and work to develop these applications, and how other chemists expand upon the ground-breaking work of previous chemists.
I gained a great intuition for thinking about chemistry. We talked a lot about experimental design, the process of making discoveries, etc.
Industrial applications of organometallic chemistry.

This course covered a variety of transformations relevant to modern organometallic chemistry. I learned a variety of industrial-valuable transformations used in both commodity and fine-chemical synthesis. At the core, I gained a better insight into deciphering complex organometallic mechanisms from analysis of results ranging from product distributions to more complex kinetic phenomena.
I learned a lot about organometallic chemistry, including important reactions, their mechanisms, and how these were studied. I gained skill in organometallic intuition about reactivity.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: excellent content and professor. Would not change anything about the content or structure of the course and Nilay is amazing. Everyone else in the class is super helpful and study groups are your friend.

Weaknesses: lectures can be really hard to follow just due to speed. I love that Nilay pauses to tell stories about once a class (it makes the 75 minutes much more bearable) which gives us time to write down stuff from the board, but I often fail to copy down everything he's saying and writing at the same time. I understand that professors are often reluctant to make lecture notes available to prevent students from skipping class, but I do wish there were a few more things posted online -- like maybe some of the schemes for reactions that we went through mechanistically, so you'd still have to come to class to learn the mechanism, but if you copied down one of the reagents/products/conditions wrong, you could check online. Not understanding how a mechanism worked only to later realize that I just miswrote a structure because I was taking notes too fast was really hard and pretty common.
The course is well-organized! Nothing to improve.

Strengths: Nilay is a great lecturer, the class is well-organized, the topics are engaging and feel very relevant to research, and the workload was fair. Weaknesses: occasionally the pacing of the lectures was a bit uneven, with the start of lecture feeling manageable and then a lot of information right at the end without time to fully process it, but overall the structure and design of the class was great.

Nilay gives a historical background of each reaction (the motivation behind its development, how scientists designed experiments to move forward), so it is great for developing scientific thinking skill.

The classes were well organized and the psets for the most part aligned with the course material. The expectations of the course felt clear and the instructor was always available for extra help, to answer more questions, etc.
This class is fantastic. Nilay is a great professor and the content is fascinating. I can't think of any weakness!
The class is well-organized.

The course is both comprehensive and relevant, and I feel that I have a heightened understanding of organometallic chemistry. This course builds logically on the skills learned in the prerequisite course. No major weaknesses to note.
The course had great content about organometallic chemistry's applications and was taught in a logical manner. If anything, perhaps the timing of the term paper could have been changed/improved.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! It's great. Take it.
Yes! Anyone works with organic chemistry can take this class.
Yes, definitely. It was really exciting to learn about more recent research in chemistry as well as strategies for our own research.

If you are genuinely interested in learning chemistry, you will like it. It's not a class you can pass just by rote-memorizing a bunch of reactions/principles. A lot of the questions he gives make you think.
Yes, it's a great elective for chem majors.
Yes, definitely!
Yes! Chem 403/404 is a great elective sequence.
Yes.
Yes, I would recommend this class to another student. I found the class highly engaging and the content very interesting. It was also taught very well.
